qas.question: Who created the first rabies vaccine?

answers.text: Louis Pasteur and Pierre Paul Émile Roux

qas.question: How many cases of Diphtheria were there in 1921?
In 1923, what was discovered to be safer to treat Diphtheria Toxin?
Who created a vaccine to treat Japanese Encephalitis?
How many deaths occurred due to Diphtheria?
The rabies vaccine was created in what year?
In what year was the diphtheria vaccine made?
What compound made the diphtheria vaccine safer to use?
Who developed the first encephalitis vaccine?
What company did Hilleman later work for?

plausible_answers.text: Louis Pasteur and Pierre Paul Émile Roux

qas.question: Who created the first encephelitis vaccine?
How many cases of encephelitis where there in 1921?
In 1923, what was discovered to be safer to treat encephelitis?
Who created a vaccine to treat United States Encephalitis?
How many deaths occurred due to encephelitis?

context: Early progress toward the development of vaccines occurred throughout this period, primarily in the form of academic and government-funded basic research directed toward the identification of the pathogens responsible for common communicable diseases. In <a5_0>1885<a5_0/> <a0_0><b10_0>Louis Pasteur and Pierre Paul Émile Roux<b10_0/><a0_0/> created the first rabies vaccine. The first diphtheria vaccines were produced in <a6_0>1914<a6_0/> from a mixture of diphtheria toxin and antitoxin (produced from the serum of an inoculated animal), but the safety of the inoculation was marginal and it was not widely used. The United States recorded <a1_0><b11_0>206,000<b11_0/><a1_0/> cases of diphtheria in 1921 resulting in <a4_0><b14_0>15,520<b14_0/><a4_0/> deaths. In 1923 parallel efforts by Gaston Ramon at the Pasteur Institute and Alexander Glenny at the Wellcome Research Laboratories (later part of GlaxoSmithKline) led to the discovery that a safer vaccine could be produced by treating diphtheria toxin with <a2_0><a7_0><b12_0>formaldehyde<b12_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/>. In 1944, <a3_0><a8_0><b13_0>Maurice Hilleman<b13_0/><a8_0/><a3_0/> of Squibb Pharmaceuticals developed the first vaccine against Japanese encephelitis. Hilleman would later move to <a9_0>Merck<a9_0/> where he would play a key role in the development of vaccines against measles, mumps, chickenpox, rubella, hepatitis A, hepatitis B, and meningitis.
